documentation:
AWS App Mesh is a service mesh based on the Envoy proxy that makes it easy to monitor and control microservices. App Mesh standardizes how your microservices communicate, giving you end-to-end visibility and helping to ensure high availability for your applications.

App Mesh gives you consistent visibility and network traffic controls for every microservice in an application. You can use App Mesh with AWS Fargate, Amazon ECS, Amazon EKS, Kubernetes on AWS, and Amazon EC2.

App Mesh supports microservice applications that use service discovery naming for their components. For more information about service discovery on Amazon ECS, see Service Discovery in the Amazon Elastic Container Service Developer Guide. Kubernetes kube-dns and coredns are supported. For more information, see DNS for Services and Pods in the Kubernetes documentation.

CreateMesh.name: CreateMesh
CreateMesh.documentation:
Creates a service mesh. A service mesh is a logical boundary for network traffic between the services that reside within it.

After you create your service mesh, you can create virtual services, virtual nodes, virtual routers, and routes to distribute traffic between the applications in your mesh.

CreateRoute.name: CreateRoute
CreateRoute.documentation:
Creates a route that is associated with a virtual router.

You can use the prefix parameter in your route specification for path-based routing of requests. For example, if your virtual service name is my-service.local and you want the route to match requests to my-service.local/metrics, your prefix should be /metrics.

If your route matches a request, you can distribute traffic to one or more target virtual nodes with relative weighting.

CreateVirtualNode.name: CreateVirtualNode
CreateVirtualNode.documentation:
Creates a virtual node within a service mesh.

A virtual node acts as a logical pointer to a particular task group, such as an Amazon ECS service or a Kubernetes deployment. When you create a virtual node, you can specify the service discovery information for your task group.

Any inbound traffic that your virtual node expects should be specified as a listener. Any outbound traffic that your virtual node expects to reach should be specified as a backend.

The response metadata for your new virtual node contains the arn that is associated with the virtual node. Set this value (either the full ARN or the truncated resource name: for example, mesh/default/virtualNode/simpleapp) as the APPMESH_VIRTUAL_NODE_NAME environment variable for your task group's Envoy proxy container in your task definition or pod spec. This is then mapped to the node.id and node.cluster Envoy parameters.

If you require your Envoy stats or tracing to use a different name, you can override the node.cluster value that is set by APPMESH_VIRTUAL_NODE_NAME with the APPMESH_VIRTUAL_NODE_CLUSTER environment variable.

CreateVirtualRouter.name: CreateVirtualRouter
CreateVirtualRouter.documentation:
Creates a virtual router within a service mesh.

Any inbound traffic that your virtual router expects should be specified as a listener.

Virtual routers handle traffic for one or more virtual services within your mesh. After you create your virtual router, create and associate routes for your virtual router that direct incoming requests to different virtual nodes.

CreateVirtualService.name: CreateVirtualService
CreateVirtualService.documentation:
Creates a virtual service within a service mesh.

A virtual service is an abstraction of a real service that is provided by a virtual node directly or indirectly by means of a virtual router. Dependent services call your virtual service by its virtualServiceName, and those requests are routed to the virtual node or virtual router that is specified as the provider for the virtual service.

DeleteMesh.name: DeleteMesh
DeleteMesh.documentation:
Deletes an existing service mesh.

You must delete all resources (virtual services, routes, virtual routers, and virtual nodes) in the service mesh before you can delete the mesh itself.

DeleteVirtualNode.name: DeleteVirtualNode
DeleteVirtualNode.documentation:
Deletes an existing virtual node.

You must delete any virtual services that list a virtual node as a service provider before you can delete the virtual node itself.

DeleteVirtualRouter.name: DeleteVirtualRouter
DeleteVirtualRouter.documentation:
Deletes an existing virtual router.

You must delete any routes associated with the virtual router before you can delete the router itself.

ListMeshes.name: ListMeshes
ListMeshes.documentation: Returns a list of existing service meshes.

ListRoutes.name: ListRoutes
ListRoutes.documentation: Returns a list of existing routes in a service mesh.

ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource
ListTagsForResource.documentation: List the tags for an App Mesh resource.

ListVirtualNodes.name: ListVirtualNodes
ListVirtualNodes.documentation: Returns a list of existing virtual nodes.

ListVirtualRouters.name: ListVirtualRouters
ListVirtualRouters.documentation: Returns a list of existing virtual routers in a service mesh.

ListVirtualServices.name: ListVirtualServices
ListVirtualServices.documentation: Returns a list of existing virtual services in a service mesh.

TagResource.name: TagResource
TagResource.documentation: Associates the specified tags to a resource with the specified resourceArn. If existing tags on a resource aren't specified in the request parameters, they aren't changed. When a resource is deleted, the tags associated with that resource are also deleted.

UpdateRoute.name: UpdateRoute
UpdateRoute.documentation: Updates an existing route for a specified service mesh and virtual router.

UpdateVirtualNode.name: UpdateVirtualNode
UpdateVirtualNode.documentation: Updates an existing virtual node in a specified service mesh.

UpdateVirtualRouter.name: UpdateVirtualRouter
UpdateVirtualRouter.documentation: Updates an existing virtual router in a specified service mesh.

UpdateVirtualService.name: UpdateVirtualService
UpdateVirtualService.documentation: Updates an existing virtual service in a specified service mesh.

VirtualRouterListener.documentation: An object that represents a virtual router listener.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual node resides in.

spec.documentation: The new virtual node specification to apply. This overwrites the existing data.

virtualNodeName.documentation: The name of the virtual node to update.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to delete.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to create the virtual service in.

tags.documentation: Optional metadata that you can apply to the virtual service to assist with categorization and organization. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. Tag keys can have a maximum character length of 128 characters, and tag values can have a maximum length of 256 characters.

virtualServiceName.documentation: The name to use for the virtual service.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual router resides in.

spec.documentation: The new virtual router specification to apply. This overwrites the existing data.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router to update.

grpcRetryEvents.documentation: Specify at least one of the valid values.

httpRetryEvents.documentation:
Specify at least one of the following values.

  • server-error – HTTP status codes 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, 505, 506, 507, 508, 510, and 511

  • gateway-error – HTTP status codes 502, 503, and 504

  • client-error – HTTP status code 409

  • stream-error – Retry on refused stream

perRetryTimeout.documentation: An object that represents a duration of time.

GrpcRetryPolicy.documentation: An object that represents a retry policy. Specify at least one value for at least one of the types of RetryEvents, a value for maxRetries, and a value for perRetryTimeout.

limit.documentation: The maximum number of tag results returned by ListTagsForResource in paginated output. When this parameter is used, ListTagsForResource returns only limit results in a single page along with a nextToken response element. You can see the remaining results of the initial request by sending another ListTagsForResource request with the returned nextToken value. This value can be between 1 and 100. If you don't use this parameter, ListTagsForResource returns up to 100 results and a nextToken value if applicable.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value returned from a previous paginated ListTagsForResource request where limit was used and the results exceeded the value of that parameter. Pagination continues from the end of the previous results that returned the nextToken value.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the resource to list the tags for.

virtualNode.documentation: The full description of your virtual node following the create call.

accessLog.documentation: The access log configuration for a virtual node.

Logging.documentation: An object that represents the logging information for a virtual node.

ServiceUnavailableException.documentation: The request has failed due to a temporary failure of the service.

virtualRouter.documentation: A full description of the virtual router that was updated.

mesh.documentation: The full description of your service mesh.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to delete the virtual router in.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router to delete.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value to include in a future ListVirtualRouters request. When the results of a ListVirtualRouters request exceed limit, you can use this value to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

virtualRouters.documentation: The list of existing virtual routers for the specified service mesh.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the route resides in.

routeName.documentation: The name of the route to describe.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router that the route is associated with.

arn.documentation: The full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the resource.

createdAt.documentation: The Unix epoch timestamp in seconds for when the resource was created.

lastUpdatedAt.documentation: The Unix epoch timestamp in seconds for when the resource was last updated.

version.documentation: The version of the resource. Resources are created at version 1, and this version is incremented each time that they're updated.

ResourceMetadata.documentation: An object that represents metadata for a resource.

ResourceInUseException.documentation: You can't delete the specified resource because it's in use or required by another resource.

virtualNode.documentation: A full description of the virtual node that was updated.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value to include in a future ListRoutes request. When the results of a ListRoutes request exceed limit, you can use this value to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

routes.documentation: The list of existing routes for the specified service mesh and virtual router.

virtualServiceName.documentation: The name of the virtual service that is acting as a virtual node backend.

VirtualServiceBackend.documentation: An object that represents a virtual service backend for a virtual node.

BadRequestException.documentation: The request syntax was malformed. Check your request syntax and try again.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual service resides in.

spec.documentation: The new virtual service specification to apply. This overwrites the existing data.

virtualServiceName.documentation: The name of the virtual service to update.

route.documentation: A full description of the route that was updated.

weightedTargets.documentation: An object that represents the targets that traffic is routed to when a request matches the route.

HttpRouteAction.documentation: An object that represents the action to take if a match is determined.

limit.documentation: The maximum number of results returned by ListRoutes in paginated output. When you use this parameter, ListRoutes returns only limit results in a single page along with a nextToken response element. You can see the remaining results of the initial request by sending another ListRoutes request with the returned nextToken value. This value can be between 1 and 100. If you don't use this parameter, ListRoutes returns up to 100 results and a nextToken value if applicable.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to list routes in.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value returned from a previous paginated ListRoutes request where limit was used and the results exceeded the value of that parameter. Pagination continues from the end of the previous results that returned the nextToken value.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router to list routes in.

healthyThreshold.documentation: The number of consecutive successful health checks that must occur before declaring listener healthy.

intervalMillis.documentation: The time period in milliseconds between each health check execution.

path.documentation: The destination path for the health check request. This is required only if the specified protocol is HTTP. If the protocol is TCP, this parameter is ignored.

port.documentation: The destination port for the health check request. This port must match the port defined in the PortMapping for the listener.

protocol.documentation: The protocol for the health check request.

timeoutMillis.documentation: The amount of time to wait when receiving a response from the health check, in milliseconds.

unhealthyThreshold.documentation: The number of consecutive failed health checks that must occur before declaring a virtual node unhealthy.

HealthCheckPolicy.documentation: An object that represents the health check policy for a virtual node's listener.

arn.documentation: The full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the virtual service.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual service resides in.

VirtualServiceRef.documentation: An object that represents a virtual service returned by a list operation.

type.documentation: The egress filter type. By default, the type is DROP_ALL, which allows egress only from virtual nodes to other defined resources in the service mesh (and any traffic to *.amazonaws.com for AWS API calls). You can set the egress filter type to ALLOW_ALL to allow egress to any endpoint inside or outside of the service mesh.

EgressFilter.documentation: An object that represents the egress filter rules for a service mesh.

status.documentation: The current status of the virtual node.

VirtualNodeStatus.documentation: An object that represents the current status of the virtual node.

arn.documentation: The full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the virtual router.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual router resides in.

VirtualRouterRef.documentation: An object that represents a virtual router returned by a list operation.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual service resides in.

status.documentation: The current status of the virtual service.

VirtualServiceData.documentation: An object that represents a virtual service returned by a describe operation.

invert.documentation: Specify True to match anything except the match criteria. The default value is False.

name.documentation: A name for the HTTP header in the client request that will be matched on.

HttpRouteHeader.documentation: An object that represents the HTTP header in the request.

virtualService.documentation: The full description of your virtual service.

arn.documentation: The full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the virtual node.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual node resides in.

VirtualNodeRef.documentation: An object that represents a virtual node returned by a list operation.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name to use for the service mesh.

tags.documentation: Optional metadata that you can apply to the service mesh to assist with categorization and organization. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. Tag keys can have a maximum character length of 128 characters, and tag values can have a maximum length of 256 characters.

weightedTargets.documentation: An object that represents the targets that traffic is routed to when a request matches the route.

GrpcRouteAction.documentation: An object that represents the action to take if a match is determined.

virtualNode.documentation: The full description of your virtual node.

LimitExceededException.documentation: You have exceeded a service limit for your account. For more information, see Service Limits in the AWS App Mesh User Guide.

route.documentation: The full description of your mesh following the create call.

exact.documentation: The value sent by the client must match the specified value exactly.

prefix.documentation: The value sent by the client must begin with the specified characters.

range.documentation: An object that represents the range of values to match on.

regex.documentation: The value sent by the client must include the specified characters.

suffix.documentation: The value sent by the client must end with the specified characters.

GrpcRouteMetadataMatchMethod.documentation: An object that represents the match method. Specify one of the match values.

hostname.documentation: Specifies the DNS service discovery hostname for the virtual node.

DnsServiceDiscovery.documentation: An object that represents the DNS service discovery information for your virtual node.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual service resides in.

virtualServiceName.documentation: The name of the virtual service to describe.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to delete the route in.

routeName.documentation: The name of the route to delete.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router to delete the route in.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual node resides in.

metadata.documentation: The associated metadata for the virtual node.

status.documentation: The current status for the virtual node.

VirtualNodeData.documentation: An object that represents a virtual node returned by a describe operation.

key.documentation: The name of an AWS Cloud Map service instance attribute key. Any AWS Cloud Map service instance that contains the specified key and value is returned.

value.documentation: The value of an AWS Cloud Map service instance attribute key. Any AWS Cloud Map service instance that contains the specified key and value is returned.

AwsCloudMapInstanceAttribute.documentation: An object that represents the AWS Cloud Map attribute information for your virtual node.

provider.documentation: The App Mesh object that is acting as the provider for a virtual service. You can specify a single virtual node or virtual router.

VirtualServiceSpec.documentation: An object that represents the specification of a virtual service.

virtualService.documentation: Specifies a virtual service to use as a backend for a virtual node.

Backend.documentation: An object that represents the backends that a virtual node is expected to send outbound traffic to.

MatchRange.documentation: An object that represents the range of values to match on. The first character of the range is included in the range, though the last character is not. For example, if the range specified were 1-100, only values 1-99 would be matched.

limit.documentation: The maximum number of results returned by ListMeshes in paginated output. When you use this parameter, ListMeshes returns only limit results in a single page along with a nextToken response element. You can see the remaining results of the initial request by sending another ListMeshes request with the returned nextToken value. This value can be between 1 and 100. If you don't use this parameter, ListMeshes returns up to 100 results and a nextToken value if applicable.

nextToken.documentation:
The nextToken value returned from a previous paginated ListMeshes request where limit was used and the results exceeded the value of that parameter. Pagination continues from the end of the previous results that returned the nextToken value.

This token should be treated as an opaque identifier that is used only to retrieve the next items in a list and not for other programmatic purposes.

action.documentation: The action to take if a match is determined.

TcpRoute.documentation: An object that represents a TCP route type.

limit.documentation: The maximum number of results returned by ListVirtualRouters in paginated output. When you use this parameter, ListVirtualRouters returns only limit results in a single page along with a nextToken response element. You can see the remaining results of the initial request by sending another ListVirtualRouters request with the returned nextToken value. This value can be between 1 and 100. If you don't use this parameter, ListVirtualRouters returns up to 100 results and a nextToken value if applicable.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to list virtual routers in.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value returned from a previous paginated ListVirtualRouters request where limit was used and the results exceeded the value of that parameter. Pagination continues from the end of the previous results that returned the nextToken value.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual router resides in.

metadata.documentation: The associated metadata for the virtual router.

status.documentation: The current status of the virtual router.

VirtualRouterData.documentation: An object that represents a virtual router returned by a describe operation.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to update.

limit.documentation: The maximum number of results returned by ListVirtualServices in paginated output. When you use this parameter, ListVirtualServices returns only limit results in a single page along with a nextToken response element. You can see the remaining results of the initial request by sending another ListVirtualServices request with the returned nextToken value. This value can be between 1 and 100. If you don't use this parameter, ListVirtualServices returns up to 100 results and a nextToken value if applicable.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to list virtual services in.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value returned from a previous paginated ListVirtualServices request where limit was used and the results exceeded the value of that parameter. Pagination continues from the end of the previous results that returned the nextToken value.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to create the virtual router in.

tags.documentation: Optional metadata that you can apply to the virtual router to assist with categorization and organization. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. Tag keys can have a maximum character length of 128 characters, and tag values can have a maximum length of 256 characters.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name to use for the virtual router.

file.documentation: The file object to send virtual node access logs to.

AccessLog.documentation: An object that represents the access logging information for a virtual node.

limit.documentation: The maximum number of results returned by ListVirtualNodes in paginated output. When you use this parameter, ListVirtualNodes returns only limit results in a single page along with a nextToken response element. You can see the remaining results of the initial request by sending another ListVirtualNodes request with the returned nextToken value. This value can be between 1 and 100. If you don't use this parameter, ListVirtualNodes returns up to 100 results and a nextToken value if applicable.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to list virtual nodes in.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value returned from a previous paginated ListVirtualNodes request where limit was used and the results exceeded the value of that parameter. Pagination continues from the end of the previous results that returned the nextToken value.

virtualRouter.documentation: The full description of your virtual router.

mesh.documentation: The full description of your service mesh following the create call.

virtualRouter.documentation: The full description of your virtual router following the create call.

status.documentation: The current status of the virtual service.

VirtualServiceStatus.documentation: An object that represents the status of a virtual service.

listeners.documentation: The listeners that the virtual router is expected to receive inbound traffic from. You can specify one listener.

VirtualRouterSpec.documentation: An object that represents the specification of a virtual router.

TooManyRequestsException.documentation: The maximum request rate permitted by the App Mesh APIs has been exceeded for your account. For best results, use an increasing or variable sleep interval between requests.

backends.documentation: The backends that the virtual node is expected to send outbound traffic to.

listeners.documentation: The listeners that the virtual node is expected to receive inbound traffic from. You can specify one listener.

logging.documentation: The inbound and outbound access logging information for the virtual node.

serviceDiscovery.documentation: The service discovery information for the virtual node. If your virtual node does not expect ingress traffic, you can omit this parameter.

VirtualNodeSpec.documentation: An object that represents the specification of a virtual node.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value to include in a future ListMeshes request. When the results of a ListMeshes request exceed limit, you can use this value to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

Duration.documentation: An object that represents a duration of time.

ConflictException.documentation: The request contains a client token that was used for a previous update resource call with different specifications. Try the request again with a new client token.

headers.documentation: An object that represents the client request headers to match on.

method.documentation: The client request method to match on. Specify only one.

prefix.documentation: Specifies the path to match requests with. This parameter must always start with /, which by itself matches all requests to the virtual service name. You can also match for path-based routing of requests. For example, if your virtual service name is my-service.local and you want the route to match requests to my-service.local/metrics, your prefix should be /metrics.

scheme.documentation: The client request scheme to match on. Specify only one.

HttpRouteMatch.documentation: An object that represents the requirements for a route to match HTTP requests for a virtual router.

key.documentation: One part of a key-value pair that make up a tag. A key is a general label that acts like a category for more specific tag values.

value.documentation: The optional part of a key-value pair that make up a tag. A value acts as a descriptor within a tag category (key).

TagRef.documentation: Optional metadata that you apply to a resource to assist with categorization and organization. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. Tag keys can have a maximum character length of 128 characters, and tag values can have a maximum length of 256 characters.

arn.documentation: The full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the service mesh.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh.

MeshRef.documentation: An object that represents a service mesh returned by a list operation.

port.documentation: The port used for the port mapping.

protocol.documentation: The protocol used for the port mapping. Specify one protocol.

PortMapping.documentation: An object that represents a port mapping.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh.

metadata.documentation: The associated metadata for the service mesh.

spec.documentation: The associated specification for the service mesh.

MeshData.documentation: An object that represents a service mesh returned by a describe operation.

status.documentation: The current status of the virtual router.

VirtualRouterStatus.documentation: An object that represents the status of a virtual router.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value to include in a future ListVirtualServices request. When the results of a ListVirtualServices request exceed limit, you can use this value to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

virtualServices.documentation: The list of existing virtual services for the specified service mesh.

virtualNode.documentation: The virtual node to associate with the weighted target.

weight.documentation: The relative weight of the weighted target.

WeightedTarget.documentation: An object that represents a target and its relative weight. Traffic is distributed across targets according to their relative weight. For example, a weighted target with a relative weight of 50 receives five times as much traffic as one with a relative weight of 10. The total weight for all targets combined must be less than or equal to 100.

weightedTargets.documentation: An object that represents the targets that traffic is routed to when a request matches the route.

TcpRouteAction.documentation: An object that represents the action to take if a match is determined.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual node resides in.

virtualNodeName.documentation: The name of the virtual node to describe.

RouteStatus.documentation: An object that represents the current status of a route.

arn.documentation: The full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the route.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the route resides in.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The virtual router that the route is associated with.

RouteRef.documentation: An object that represents a route returned by a list operation.

healthCheck.documentation: The health check information for the listener.

portMapping.documentation: The port mapping information for the listener.

Listener.documentation: An object that represents a listener for a virtual node.

action.documentation: An object that represents the action to take if a match is determined.

match.documentation: An object that represents the criteria for determining a request match.

retryPolicy.documentation: An object that represents a retry policy.

GrpcRoute.documentation: An object that represents a GRPC route type.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to delete the virtual node in.

virtualNodeName.documentation: The name of the virtual node to delete.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the route resides in.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The virtual router that the route is associated with.

RouteData.documentation: An object that represents a route returned by a describe operation.

virtualNodeName.documentation: The name of the virtual node that is acting as a service provider.

VirtualNodeServiceProvider.documentation: An object that represents a virtual node service provider.

InternalServerErrorException.documentation: The request processing has failed because of an unknown error, exception, or failure.

httpRetryEvents.documentation:
Specify at least one of the following values.

  • server-error – HTTP status codes 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, 505, 506, 507, 508, 510, and 511

  • gateway-error – HTTP status codes 502, 503, and 504

  • client-error – HTTP status code 409

  • stream-error – Retry on refused stream

perRetryTimeout.documentation: An object that represents a duration of time.

HttpRetryPolicy.documentation: An object that represents a retry policy. Specify at least one value for at least one of the types of RetryEvents, a value for maxRetries, and a value for perRetryTimeout.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the virtual router resides in.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router to describe.

ForbiddenException.documentation: You don't have permissions to perform this action.

TooManyTagsException.documentation: The request exceeds the maximum allowed number of tags allowed per resource. The current limit is 50 user tags per resource. You must reduce the number of tags in the request. None of the tags in this request were applied.

exact.documentation: The value sent by the client must match the specified value exactly.

prefix.documentation: The value sent by the client must begin with the specified characters.

range.documentation: An object that represents the range of values to match on.

regex.documentation: The value sent by the client must include the specified characters.

suffix.documentation: The value sent by the client must end with the specified characters.

HeaderMatchMethod.documentation: An object that represents the method and value to match with the header value sent in a request. Specify one match method.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to add tags to.

tags.documentation: The tags to add to the resource. A tag is an array of key-value pairs. Tag keys can have a maximum character length of 128 characters, and tag values can have a maximum length of 256 characters.

invert.documentation: Specify True to match anything except the match criteria. The default value is False.

match.documentation: An object that represents the data to match from the request.

GrpcRouteMetadata.documentation: An object that represents the match metadata for the route.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to create the route in.

routeName.documentation: The name to use for the route.

tags.documentation: Optional metadata that you can apply to the route to assist with categorization and organization. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. Tag keys can have a maximum character length of 128 characters, and tag values can have a maximum length of 256 characters.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router in which to create the route.

virtualNode.documentation: The virtual node associated with a virtual service.

virtualRouter.documentation: The virtual router associated with a virtual service.

VirtualServiceProvider.documentation: An object that represents the provider for a virtual service.

metadata.documentation: An object that represents the data to match from the request.

methodName.documentation: The method name to match from the request. If you specify a name, you must also specify a serviceName.

serviceName.documentation: The fully qualified domain name for the service to match from the request.

GrpcRouteMatch.documentation: An object that represents the criteria for determining a request match.

attributes.documentation: A string map that contains attributes with values that you can use to filter instances by any custom attribute that you specified when you registered the instance. Only instances that match all of the specified key/value pairs will be returned.

namespaceName.documentation: The name of the AWS Cloud Map namespace to use.

serviceName.documentation: The name of the AWS Cloud Map service to use.

AwsCloudMapServiceDiscovery.documentation: An object that represents the AWS Cloud Map service discovery information for your virtual node.

virtualService.documentation: A full description of the virtual service that was updated.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh that the route resides in.

routeName.documentation: The name of the route to update.

spec.documentation: The new route specification to apply. This overwrites the existing data.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router that the route is associated with.

MeshStatus.documentation: An object that represents the status of a service mesh.

clientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Up to 36 letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to create the virtual node in.

tags.documentation: Optional metadata that you can apply to the virtual node to assist with categorization and organization. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. Tag keys can have a maximum character length of 128 characters, and tag values can have a maximum length of 256 characters.

virtualNodeName.documentation: The name to use for the virtual node.

NotFoundException.documentation: The specified resource doesn't exist. Check your request syntax and try again.

grpcRoute.documentation: An object that represents the specification of a GRPC route.

http2Route.documentation: An object that represents the specification of an HTTP2 route.

httpRoute.documentation: An object that represents the specification of an HTTP route.

priority.documentation: The priority for the route. Routes are matched based on the specified value, where 0 is the highest priority.

tcpRoute.documentation: An object that represents the specification of a TCP route.

RouteSpec.documentation: An object that represents a route specification. Specify one route type.

action.documentation: An object that represents the action to take if a match is determined.

match.documentation: An object that represents the criteria for determining a request match.

retryPolicy.documentation: An object that represents a retry policy.

HttpRoute.documentation: An object that represents an HTTP or HTTP2 route type.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to describe.

egressFilter.documentation: The egress filter rules for the service mesh.

MeshSpec.documentation: An object that represents the specification of a service mesh.

virtualService.documentation: The full description of your virtual service following the create call.

path.documentation:
The file path to write access logs to. You can use /dev/stdout to send access logs to standard out and configure your Envoy container to use a log driver, such as awslogs, to export the access logs to a log storage service such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs. You can also specify a path in the Envoy container's file system to write the files to disk.

The Envoy process must have write permissions to the path that you specify here. Otherwise, Envoy fails to bootstrap properly.

FileAccessLog.documentation: An object that represents an access log file.

virtualRouterName.documentation: The name of the virtual router that is acting as a service provider.

VirtualRouterServiceProvider.documentation: An object that represents a virtual node service provider.

meshName.documentation: The name of the service mesh to delete the virtual service in.

virtualServiceName.documentation: The name of the virtual service to delete.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value to include in a future ListTagsForResource request. When the results of a ListTagsForResource request exceed limit, you can use this value to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

awsCloudMap.documentation: Specifies any AWS Cloud Map information for the virtual node.

dns.documentation: Specifies the DNS information for the virtual node.

ServiceDiscovery.documentation: An object that represents the service discovery information for a virtual node.

nextToken.documentation: The nextToken value to include in a future ListVirtualNodes request. When the results of a ListVirtualNodes request exceed limit, you can use this value to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

virtualNodes.documentation: The list of existing virtual nodes for the specified service mesh.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to delete tags from.

tagKeys.documentation: The keys of the tags to be removed.
